commit_message:
fup: Require python >= 3.8 from Yoga

While I314fd61f20f2c3551f6231d191b7dcaaefabd2b5 dropped support for <
3.8 it did not require >= 3.8 to be used. As discussed if we are no
  longer testing older versions of python or listing them as supported
runtimes then we should block their use entirely.

This Depends-On the following Tempest change dropping the CentOS 8
Stream integrated compute job from the template for master as Nova will
no longer install on it with this change.

Depends-On: https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/tempest/+/819413

Additionally this change also Depends-On the following
openstack-zuul-jobs change moving the lower-constraints job to Focal and
py38 so that is also in-line with the new runtime requirements.

Depends-On: https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/openstack-zuul-jobs/+/819431

Change-Id: I310726335e1dcdb12c1323be18405122dcc75cc2
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/15/819415/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: python_requires = >=3.8

commit_message:
Make nova::compute::libvirt_guests works in Debian

This patch makes nova::compute::libvirt_guests works for non-RedHat
systems, and also add 2 new tweaks: number of parallel shutdown of
VMs, and delay when starting them.

Change-Id: I638143191f00650602f759d359cdbc7c5eb48798

commit_message:
Replace genisoimage with xorriso

genisoimage has been removed from RHEL-9 and is replaced with
xorriso.

This patch updates the package map to xorriso instead of
replacing the genisoimage key map to avoid the breakage for
other distros.

Closes-Bug: #1953013

Signed-off-by: Chandan Kumar (raukadah) <chkumar@redhat.com>
Change-Id: I31f6d4f080afd93ae067c37348e9ef570f0a34d4
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/ironic-python-agent-builder refs/changes/24/820124/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: "genisoimage": "xorriso",

commit_message:
Fix VLAN ID management

It seems like we weren't paying attention to VLAN ID management when
handling errors on bulk port create requests. This commit fixes that by
making sure VLAN IDs are released if that happens.

Interestingly, we haven't really seen this affecting too much as in case
of these error Kuryr would restart thanks to health checks. But once you
stop restarting, the VLAN ID pool may get exhausted pretty soon.

Closes-Bug: 1951443
Change-Id: I7e51ff455baefd08c9fb167885ddcaa9025dedb4

commit_message:
Retry image download if it's corrupted

Adding IOError in list of catching exceptions in order to
fix behavior when nova-compute wouldn't retry image download
when got "Corrupt image download" error from glanceclient
and had num_retries config option set.

Closes-Bug: #1950657
Change-Id: Iae4fd0579f71d3ba6793dbdb037275352d7e57b0
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/03/818503/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: --- fixes: - | `Bug 1950657 <https://bugs.launchpad.net/nova/+bug/1950657>`_, fixing behavior when nova-compute wouldn't retry image download when gets "Corrupt image download" error from glanceclient and has num_retries config option set.

commit_message:
Turn crush_hierarchy path into var content

Like we've done for the osd_spec, the tripleclient command provides
a path file where the crush hierarchy is defined.
This task looks for the content of the hierarchy file, turning it
into a var content that is passed to the ceph_spec_bootstrap module.

Change-Id: I09242a8cf6286dc5b9263afb2e22b8d5cdad49f1
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/tripleo-ansible refs/changes/16/820116/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: - name: Override crush hierarchy if a custom crush path is provided set_fact: crush_hierarchy: "{{ crush_spec_content | from_yaml }}" vars: crush_spec_content: "{{ lookup('file', crush_hierarchy_path) }}" when: - crush_hierarchy_path is defined - crush_hierarchy_path | length > 0 crush_hierarchy: "{{ crush_hierarchy | default({}) }}"

subject: Fix gnocchi filter project for non-default domain
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2021-12-03 09:05:57.000000000', 'files': ['ceilometer/publisher/gnocchi.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/ceilometer/commit/85c8e1c6fc545d2cb995fbfe6019a7e26ef1d5e6', 'message': 'Fix gnocchi filter project for non-default domain

the keystoneclient calls used were wrong, and basically ignored
any filter_domain value, parsing all the projects.
This leads to failures to resolve project if when for example several
projects with the same name exist in different domains.

This patch adapts the resolution to proper calls - first resolve the
name of the domain to ID, than use that ID in the call to resolve the
project.

Change-Id: I91e509aa5427ee060e02591f719a815f71768618
'}]
commit_message:
Fix gnocchi filter project for non-default domain

the keystoneclient calls used were wrong, and basically ignored
any filter_domain value, parsing all the projects.
This leads to failures to resolve project if when for example several
projects with the same name exist in different domains.

This patch adapts the resolution to proper calls - first resolve the
name of the domain to ID, than use that ID in the call to resolve the
project.

Change-Id: I91e509aa5427ee060e02591f719a815f71768618
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/ceilometer refs/changes/55/820355/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
Optimize cluster list api

Up till now, cluster api controller cluster_template_id was a
property field loading the id from the DB every time. With this
change the field becomes of text type and mandatory, so wsme fwk
guarantees that the field is provided when needed.

Cluster objects will not load the cluster template on creation.
Instead cluster templates will be loaded when they are actually
needed.

story: 2006693
task: 36989

Co-Authored-By: Stavros Moiras <stavros.moiras@cern.ch>

Change-Id: I2313c6a8b647e521cfa476f9cec65ab286fa5a23
(cherry picked from commit 0792885a1b2c5f5d93f48bd07b9a169c2096669f)

commit_message:
Pass crush hierarchy data as extra_var

When the Ceph cluster is run, for each OSD the operator can define
an osd crush location (like it used to do with ceph-ansible [1]).
This patch adds to the overcloud ceph deploy command the ability to
accept an additional argument that represents the path where the
hierarchy map is defined.

[1] https://github.com/ceph/ceph-ansible/blob/master/tests/functional/all_daemons/container/hosts

Change-Id: Idd0296928246359e2dbb95f5163f32b653af55a3
(cherry picked from commit f49649074a4f512de3bc6948b463a6e270d4a3e0)
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/python-tripleoclient refs/changes/00/820100/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: spec_group.add_argument('--crush-hierarchy', help=_( "Path to an existing crush hierarchy spec " "file. "), default=None) if parsed_args.crush_hierarchy: if not os.path.exists(parsed_args.crush_hierarchy): raise oscexc.CommandError( "Crush Hierarchy Spec file not found --crush-hierarchy %s." % os.path.abspath(parsed_args.crush_hierarchy)) else: extra_vars['crush_hierarchy_path'] = \ os.path.abspath(parsed_args.crush_hierarchy)

commit_message:
Add centos9 support for emit_releases_script

emit_releases_file needed to be updated to support centos9 and
integration pipeline.
The tests have been only partially updated: added the success
scenario to cover the centos9 case.

Change-Id: I4e35a0ce1c7b38a7e354c4571ac6a005697632d7

commit_message:
Database connection pooling improvements

- Implemented new variable ``connection_recycle_time`` responsible for SQLAlchemy's connection recycling
- Set new default values for db pooling variables which are inherited from the global ones.

capture EC frag lengths in unit test

addresses a TODO from [1]

git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/swift refs/changes/42/820142/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: orig_decode = self.policy.pyeclib_driver.decode captured_fragments = [] def mock_decode(fragments): captured_fragments.append(fragments) return orig_decode(fragments) # sanity check responses1 and capture frag lengths with mock.patch.object( self.policy.pyeclib_driver, 'decode', mock_decode): resp = req.get_response(self.app) self.assertEqual(resp.status_int, 200) # read body while decode is mocked self.assertEqual( md5(resp.body, usedforsecurity=False).hexdigest(), etag1) fragment_lengths1 = [[len(frag) for frag in frags] for frags in captured_fragments] self.assertEqual( # sanity check len(ec_archive_bodies1[0]), sum([length for length in [lengths[0] for lengths in fragment_lengths1]])) # sanity check responses2 and capture frag lengths captured_fragments = [] with mock.patch.object( self.policy.pyeclib_driver, 'decode', mock_decode): resp = req.get_response(self.app) self.assertEqual(resp.status_int, 200) # read body while decode is mocked self.assertEqual( md5(resp.body, usedforsecurity=False).hexdigest(), etag2) fragment_lengths2 = [[len(frag) for frag in frags] for frags in captured_fragments] self.assertEqual( # sanity check len(ec_archive_bodies2[0]), sum([length for length in [lengths[0] for lengths in fragment_lengths2]])) num_segments = len(fragment_lengths1) mixed_lengths = fragment_lengths1[num_segments - 1] mixed_lengths[mix_index] = fragment_lengths2[ num_segments - 1][mix_index] self.assertIn('Segments decoded: %d' % (num_segments - 1), msg) self.assertIn( "[%s]" % ", ".join([str(length) for length in mixed_lengths]), msg)
deleted_lines: # sanity check responses1 resp = req.get_response(self.app) self.assertEqual(resp.status_int, 200) self.assertEqual( md5(resp.body, usedforsecurity=False).hexdigest(), etag1) # sanity check responses2 resp = req.get_response(self.app) self.assertEqual(resp.status_int, 200) self.assertEqual( md5(resp.body, usedforsecurity=False).hexdigest(), etag2) # TODO(mattoliverau): find out how to get these numbers dynamically # cause who know's they may vary based on arch or even python # verions :shrug: mixed_lengths = ["458" for _ in responses1[:self.policy.ec_ndata]] mixed_lengths[mix_index] = '490' self.assertIn('Segments decoded: 3', msg) self.assertIn("[%s]" % ", ".join(mixed_lengths), msg)

commit_message:
Add job for validating logscraper and log gearman services

We want to ensure that all services that have been deployed
are running correctly before merging new change.

Change-Id: I513aa328e720749130fafcd82920585ff99b867c
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/ci-log-processing refs/changes/09/818809/4 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: --- - hosts: all become: true vars: # logscraper tenant_builds: - tenant: openstack gearman_port: 4730 gearman_server: 0.0.0.0 zuul_api_url: https://zuul.opendev.org/api/tenant/openstack zuul_api_urls: - https://zuul.opendev.org/api/tenant/openstack insecure: false job_names: [] # loggearman - client source_url: https://0.0.0.0 # loggearman - worker output_host: 0.0.0.0 output_port: 9999 gearman_host: 0.0.0.0 gearman_port: 4730 log_cert_verify: false tasks: - name: Install packages package: name: podman state: present ### OPENSEARCH #### - name: Setup Opensearch shell: > podman run -d --name opensearch \ --network host \ -e "discovery.type=single-node" \ quay.rdoproject.org/software-factory/opensearch:1.1.0 - name: Wait for Opensearch to be up wait_for: host: 0.0.0.0 port: 9200 delay: 10 timeout: 300 - name: Ensure Opensearch is up uri: url: "https://localhost:9200" user: "admin" password: "admin" force_basic_auth: true method: GET validate_certs: false status_code: 200 ### LOGSTASH ### - name: Create require directories for Logstash file: path: "/etc/logstash/conf.d" state: directory recurse: true owner: '1000' group: '1000' - name: Create Logstash config copy: content: | # opensearch analyze is working on 9600 http.port: 9601 http.host: 0.0.0.0 dest: /etc/logstash/logstash.yml mode: '0644' owner: '1000' group: '1000' - name: Setup pipeline configuration copy: content: | input { tcp { host => "0.0.0.0" port => "9999" codec => json_lines {} type => "zuul" } } filter { grok { match => ["message", "(?<timestamp>[-0-9]{10}\s+[0-9.:]{12})(?<ms>[0-9]{3}) (?<sep>\|)%{GREEDYDATA:message}"] overwrite => [ "message" ] } if [message] =~ /^\s*$/ { drop { } } date { match => ["timestamp", "yyyy-MM-dd HH:mm:ss.SSS"] timezone => "UTC" } } output { elasticsearch { hosts => ['https://0.0.0.0:9200'] index => "logstash-logscraper-%{+YYYY.MM.dd}" user => 'admin' password => "admin" ssl => true ssl_certificate_verification => false ilm_enabled => false } } dest: /etc/logstash/conf.d/logscraper.conf mode: '0644' owner: '1000' group: '1000' - name: Setup Logstash service shell: > podman run -d --name logstash \ --network host \ -v /etc/logstash/conf.d:/usr/share/logstash/pipeline:z \ -v /etc/logstash/logstash.yml:/usr/share/logstash/config/logstash.yml:z \ quay.rdoproject.org/software-factory/logstash:7.10.1 - name: Wait for Logstash to be up wait_for: host: 0.0.0.0 port: 9999 delay: 10 timeout: 300 ### Loggearman ### - name: Setup loggearman service include_role: name: loggearman ### Logscraper ### - name: Setup logscraper service include_role: name: logscraper # Flush handlers before running test - name: Force all notified handlers to run now meta: flush_handlers ### service validation ### - name: Ensure that all services are available and running shell: | systemctl is-active -q {{ item }} loop: - logscraper-openstack - loggearman-client - loggearman-worker register: _service_status failed_when: _service_status.rc != 0 - name: Check if log gearman client is listening wait_for: host: "{{ gearman_host }}" port: "{{ gearman_port }}" delay: 10 timeout: 300 - name: Wait for scrape logs pause: seconds: 30 - name: Get Opensearch indices uri: url: "https://localhost:9200/_cat/indices" user: "admin" password: "admin" force_basic_auth: true method: GET validate_certs: false status_code: 200 return_content: true register: _opensearch_indices failed_when: "'logstash-logscraper' not in _opensearch_indices.content"

commit_message:
Dropping lower constraints testing (stable Xena)

This topic was discussed on the ML and QA team proposed to
to test lower-constraints [1].

As decided in Neutron meeting, stable branches will drop this
CI job [2]. This matches the patch for Neutron [3].

[1]http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-discuss/2020-December/019390.html
[2]http://eavesdrop.openstack.org/meetings/networking/2021/networking.2021-01-12-14.00.log.html
[3] I9559c5810d0dfff0793cb3094e007a9cb8f681c6

Signed-off-by: Dr. Jens Harbott <harbott@osism.tech>
Change-Id: I573114989afb66369ba94a9f62671af33e6fb1a1

subject: The default max/min tx rates shall not halt deployment
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2021-12-01 15:18:18.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/os-net-config/commit/e93f4c4c3b9eaceb9f02539453552b51efd2dda1', 'message': 'The default max/min tx rates shall not halt deployment.

The default configuration of max_tx_rate and min_tx_rate is 0.
Some of the SR-IOV driver implementation throws up the error for
the default values and the errors shall be safely handled instead
of raising an exception.

Change-Id: I0e6ee35e327d36ddc1b792de1ee48bad609bc3ad
'}, {'number': 2, 'created': '2021-12-02 03:49:14.000000000', 'files': ['os_net_config/sriov_config.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/os-net-config/commit/44eab2297f4db36ede6d29a18be60da800266f01', 'message': 'The default max/min tx rates shall not halt deployment

The default configuration of max_tx_rate and min_tx_rate is 0.
Some of the SR-IOV driver implementation throws up the error for
the default values and the errors shall be safely handled instead
of raising an exception.

commit_message:
The default max/min tx rates shall not halt deployment

The default configuration of max_tx_rate and min_tx_rate is 0.
Some of the SR-IOV driver implementation throws up the error for
the default values and the errors shall be safely handled instead
of raising an exception.

Change-Id: I0e6ee35e327d36ddc1b792de1ee48bad609bc3ad

commit_message:
Don't use patch update

We use PATCH update that ensures existing resource_registry
and parameters in the stack environment are used. Not using
those would be a key requirement for an ephemeral heat stack.

Change-Id: I7162cc3a6bb9ff5eed0bc516f0933995a543f461

commit_message:
Actually disconnect NVMe drive on disconnect_volume()

disconnect_volume() is missing actual NVMe-oF
initiator disconnect command. This causes
unusable ghost drives to be present in a system
after disconnecting volume from node.

Signed-off-by: Maciej Szwed <maciej.szwed@intel.com>
Change-Id: I8e14a55c3e376d427ce39b1ae1feb906326a13c9
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/os-brick refs/changes/05/817005/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
k8s_api: add a request timeout for the Kubernetes API

There is currently no API timeout for the Kubernetes API
client which means that if for some reason it gets stuck
trying to talk to a cluster, it'll block the whole process
forever.

This patch adds a reasonable 15 second timeout which will
raise an exception during the health check instead of
deadlocking the process.

Change-Id: I418a3a4e14f8b1c67418ed6e62df896eb90ea530
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/magnum refs/changes/81/818781/3 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # NOTE(mnaser): Since the default timeout is None, we need to set # a default value, otherwise the requests will never # timeout and the conductor will end up in a deadlock. if _request_timeout is None: _request_timeout = 15

commit_message:
Fix the instances pagination integration tests

Looks like the popup that comes up after creating instances is no
longer a SUCCESS, but instead it's INFO.

This patch fixes integration tests which were using the incorrect
message class and revisits all other tests skipped with the same
bug number reason.

Change-Id: I0e2976b56513df3cb45ea00e0f9f05603a8743a8
Closes-bug: #1774697

commit_message:
Add hacking check D710 for LOG.warn()

Python 3 deprecated the logger.warn method, see:
https://docs.python.org/3/library/logging.html#logging.warning
so we prefer to use warning to avoid DeprecationWarning.

This patch adds a hacking check, similar to other projects, that enforces
using LOG.warning() instead of LOG.warn().

Change-Id: I424ccc14ec09dd6c7662aaee1096dfd56917aef2
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/designate refs/changes/34/819734/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

subject: Fix namespace-less containers in image-serve
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2021-11-10 22:21:41.000000000', 'files': ['tripleo_common/image/image_export.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/tripleo-common/commit/9e10876bd8c8daca6c656ab96571cc9b64ab54cc', 'message': 'Fix namespace-less containers in image-serve

The build_catalog() function expects the manifests, tags and blobs be
available before the catalog will recognized a container image. The
previous spot where this function was called was after the manifests but
before the tags are created.  This causes the newly uploaded container
not to be listed in the catalog. This change moves the build_catalog()
to last so new images get correctly added to the catalog.

Change-Id: I3f08fe0efef1e830b034fab06574a05dff89ccc0
Closes-Bug: #1950352
(cherry picked from commit f8eeb0dd834ecd0faae05161cef4a38211894a7a)
'}]
commit_message:
Fix namespace-less containers in image-serve

The build_catalog() function expects the manifests, tags and blobs be
available before the catalog will recognized a container image. The
previous spot where this function was called was after the manifests but
before the tags are created.  This causes the newly uploaded container
not to be listed in the catalog. This change moves the build_catalog()
to last so new images get correctly added to the catalog.

Change-Id: I3f08fe0efef1e830b034fab06574a05dff89ccc0
Closes-Bug: #1950352
(cherry picked from commit f8eeb0dd834ecd0faae05161cef4a38211894a7a)

commit_message:
Test delete security group will clear its associated rules

Test delete security group, its associated security group rules are also
deleted

Change-Id: Iae7e648730d504a13da69d72ff8912621d94a42a

added_lines: @decorators.idempotent_id('fd1ea1c5-eedc-403f-898d-2b562e853f2e') def test_delete_security_group_clear_associated_rules(self): """Test delete security group, its associated security group rules are also deleted""" group_create_body, _ = self._create_security_group() # Create rules for tcp protocol client = self.security_group_rules_client rule_create_body = client.create_security_group_rule( security_group_id=group_create_body['security_group']['id'], protocol='tcp', direction='ingress', ethertype=self.ethertype ) rule_id = rule_create_body['security_group_rule']['id'] # Delete security group self._delete_security_group(group_create_body['security_group']['id']) # List rules and verify created rule is not in response rule_list_body = ( self.security_group_rules_client.list_security_group_rules()) rule_list = [rule['id'] for rule in rule_list_body['security_group_rules']] self.assertNotIn(rule_id, rule_list)

commit_message:
Allow TXT record over 255 characters if split

As defined in RFC1035 section 3.3.14 TXT-DATA
can be one or more <character-strings>s.
Before this commit Designate threw errors
when saving TXT records that are split
into multiple strings because validations on
the field did not consider allowing this
in a single DNS record as per RFC7208
section 3.3.

This patch allows longer TXT record data
but only if it is split according to RFC
definitions mentioned above. If data
is made of more <character-string>s,
each one is individually validated with
the same validations as if the data was
not split.

Closes-Bug: 1595265
Change-Id: I4e3e51b32ab01efc4202c297708eff5a2e2b4985
Signed-off-by: Emanuel Andrecut (emanuel.andrecut@fleio.com)
(cherry picked from commit 03a5d5d74eb5de3f37b2e7ac5f28ae139ae436a5)
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/designate refs/changes/88/818888/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: If you want to construct a ``TXT`` record that exceeds the 255-octet maximum length of a character-string, it has to be split into multiple strings as defined in RFC7208 section 3.3. For example, ``"v=DKIM1; .... firstsecond string..."`` can become ``"v=DKIM1; .... first" "second string..."``. If you provide a record data with less than 255 characters, it will be treated as a single character-string and validated for empty spaces outside quotes and unescaped double quotation marks as in RFC1035 section 5.1. For example, to create a ``TXT`` record made of one string of 410 characters you can split it into 2 to like this: .. code-block:: console $ openstack recordset create --type TXT --record '"210 characters string" "200 characters string"' example.org. _domainkey

commit_message:
Add the 'remove-disk' action and enhance the 'add-disk' one

This patchset implements the remove-disk action, which, as the name
implies, removes a previously registered device from the Ceph OSD.
Additionally, it outputs a message indicating the user how the removed
disk could be replaced by another one, by providing the appropriate flags
to do so. Furthermore, the 'add-disk' action has been enhanced, so that
it can now create bcache devices automatically.

Change-Id: Ib6ec3dceafb905a565a9fc6fd25148811b967a8a
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/charm-ceph-osd refs/changes/75/818175/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: bcache-device: type: string description: | If provided, a bcache device will be created, with the provided osd-device(s) being used as backing storage, whereas the bcache-device will be used for the caching size. partition-size: | If provided, it will specify the size (in GB) of the partitions created for the caching of the bcache devices. For each osd-device, there will be a partition of this size used for its caching.remove-disk: description: | Remove disk(s) from Ceph. params: osd-devices: type: string description: The space-sparated list of osd volumes to be removed. destroy: type: boolean default: false description: | Whether to also remove the volume groups and logical volumes associated to the devices. Defaults to 'false'. format: type: string default: text enum: - text - json description: | The output format (text|json) in which to show how the removed disks may be replaced afterwards. required: - osd-devices

commit_message:
Remove event added in KuryrNetwork's on_finalize

This commit removes creation of RemoveNeutronResourcesFailed event when
there's a problem on KuryrNetwork deletion. The event can only happen
when the Namespace related to the KuryrNetwork is being removed, meaning
that we're not able to create any object there, including Events.
Moreover the situation Event warns about is fairly common, indicating
that the pods in the process of being deleted from the namespace and
that haven't finished yet.

Change-Id: Ibb321ecdd6acf876320cfbabd77580addbc6359f

commit_message:
Make pools population dynamic

To avoid using ports_pool_update_frequency, which defines
how often the pool should be updated, we could instead
make the pool population learn from previous populations
and decide when to populate. This commit is an attempt
to only make another population happen when all the
duration of last population has happened.

Change-Id: Ie5e544767c34c8bce26f2ede48e1f6ed1ab40677
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/kuryr-kubernetes refs/changes/18/819318/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # Other attempts from population should be blocked till # first has been complete or the request VIFs duration # has already passed last_update = pool_updates.get(security_groups) pool_duration = self._request_vifs_duration.get(pool_key) if not pool_duration or (now - pool_duration < last_update): LOG.warning("Not enough time since the last pool update") else: # Starting first Population self._last_update[pool_key] = {security_groups: 0} self._request_vifs_duration[pool_key] = 0 LOG.warning("Requesting %s for %s", num_ports, pool_key) start_time = time.time() time_for_vifs = time.time() - start_time for vif, port in vifs: self._last_update[pool_key] = {security_groups: time.time()} self._request_vifs_duration[pool_key] = time_for_vifs self._request_vifs_duration = collections.defaultdict()
deleted_lines: last_update = 0 last_update = pool_updates.get(security_groups, 0) try: if (now - oslo_cfg.CONF.vif_pool.ports_pool_update_frequency < last_update): LOG.debug("Not enough time since the last pool update") return except AttributeError: LOG.debug("Kuryr-controller not yet ready to populate pools.") self._last_update[pool_key] = {security_groups: now} for vif in vifs: if not vifs: self._last_update[pool_key] = {security_groups: last_update}

commit_message:
Fix pool update with duplicate masters

If any zones exist that belong to a pool that has any duplicate masters
among all targets, currently updating the pool will fail.

This change fixes the issue by ensuring the pool target master list does
not contain duplicates.

Change-Id: I72bae79b4f8e0bab739875d6f783abdb4868950b
Closes-Bug: #1897936
(cherry picked from commit 4e86bc2a58f00371a2f22217cb8a79e5ac33677c)

commit_message:
Add cooperative_yield() to OvsdbIdl

On python-ovs 2.16.0+, overriding cooperative_yield() will allow
potentially long-running CPU-intensive methods to cooperatively
yield to greenthreads. This patch + ovs 2.16.0+ will resolve
the related bug. I'll see if I can get cooperative_yield
backported in OVS as well.

Related-Bug: #1929446
Change-Id: Ibd3c7427cbcab81253e0ed700174be09908bdef7
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/ovsdbapp refs/changes/46/818446/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: def cooperative_yield(self): time.sleep(0)

commit_message:
Add "isort" library to blacklist

"pylint" requires a class named "SortImports", not present in
"isort" versions >=5.0.0. Until "pylint" fixes this problem, we
should allow each projecty to install its own "isort" library
version to unblock CI pep8 jobs.

Change-Id: I158bcc8c249ad7ec981707c0d96ad8db87eb23d9
Related-Bug: #1886422
(cherry picked from commit be1dca06e04a68e6ad02f293369124d3c24875ba)
(cherry picked from commit 8489fb44bccf16640941114854f70c6df99b8783)

commit_message:
Configure HAProxy to check Horizon's login page

This makes sure that a 500 error returned by Horizon will be caught by
HAProxy. By checking / we were always getting a 302 redirect to the
login page and were therefore missing any 500 error behind.

Change-Id: Ibd22a1697d0f3106531f1126a75dedbd7f2538ed
(cherry picked from commit 92f8639ec25a08313b78e27d8439dd8dd35b2ee0)

commit_message:
Configure HAProxy to check Horizon's login page

This makes sure that a 500 error returned by Horizon will be caught by
HAProxy. By checking / we were always getting a 302 redirect to the
login page and were therefore missing any 500 error behind.

Change-Id: Ibd22a1697d0f3106531f1126a75dedbd7f2538ed
(cherry picked from commit 92f8639ec25a08313b78e27d8439dd8dd35b2ee0)

commit_message:
Fix pool update with duplicate masters

If any zones exist that belong to a pool that has any duplicate masters
among all targets, currently updating the pool will fail.

This change fixes the issue by ensuring the pool target master list does
not contain duplicates.

Change-Id: I72bae79b4f8e0bab739875d6f783abdb4868950b
Closes-Bug: #1897936
(cherry picked from commit 4e86bc2a58f00371a2f22217cb8a79e5ac33677c)

document that binary images are now deprecated

Support for binary images gets removed in Z cycle.

Change-Id: I9cd93a2022d6b9d17f326d55d57f86cb5e141e7d

commit_message:
Replace deprecated assertDictContainsSubset

The method is deprecated since Python 3.2[1] and shows the following
DeprecationWarning.

/usr/lib/python3.9/unittest/case.py:1134: DeprecationWarning:
assertDictContainsSubset is deprecated
  warnings.warn('assertDictContainsSubset is deprecated',

[1] https://docs.python.org/3/whatsnew/3.2.html#unittest

Closes-Bug: #1938103
Change-Id: Ib1f000a7d5d0f94d7b844f8086a9798f28a44643

commit_message:
Support filtering on zone import/export list

List operations should add the task_type criterion to the user
provided criterion.

This patch also fixes the neutron-tempest-plugin-designate-scenario
job to use the ussuri version neutron-tempest-plugin-designate-scenario-ussuri.
This is required for this patch to merge.

Change-Id: I983d930f975c109cce24a9587bba6db563b3f19f
Launchpad: 1926058
(cherry picked from commit fb9f0b33d338037365f5c9dae20f4f795b119d13)
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/designate refs/changes/47/817547/5 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: if not criterion: criterion = { 'task_type': 'IMPORT' } else: criterion['task_type'] = 'IMPORT' if not criterion: criterion = { 'task_type': 'EXPORT' } else: criterion['task_type'] = 'EXPORT'

commit_message:
nb: provide lrp_get method

This change adds function and command to get only one logical router
port by name or uuid.

Closes-Bug: #1948947
Change-Id: I8395cc22d7143a53bb507876a62d923ea3874602

commit_message:
nb: add support for set of addresses API

This change adds functions and commands to add, delete, list, get and
update sets of addresses.

Closes-Bug: #1951110
Change-Id: I9390bf5e3586a3dd28c3743d06578c2a8f262e77
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/ovsdbapp refs/changes/90/818090/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: class TestAddressSetOps(OvnNorthboundTest): def setUp(self): super(TestAddressSetOps, self).setUp() self.table = self.api.tables['Address_Set'] def _addr_set_add(self, name=None, *args, **kwargs): if name is None: name = utils.get_rand_name() fix = self.useFixture(fixtures.AddressSetFixture(self.api, name, *args, **kwargs)) self.assertIn(fix.obj.uuid, self.table.rows) return fix.obj def _test_addr_set_get(self, col): addr_set = self._addr_set_add() val = getattr(addr_set, col) found = self.api.address_set_get(val).execute(check_error=True) self.assertEqual(addr_set, found) def test_addr_set_get_uuid(self): self._test_addr_set_get('uuid') def test_addr_set_get_name(self): self._test_addr_set_get('name') def test_addr_set_add_name(self): name = utils.get_rand_device_name() addr_set = self._addr_set_add(name) self.assertEqual(name, addr_set.name) def test_addr_set_add_exists(self): name = utils.get_rand_device_name() self._addr_set_add(name) cmd = self.api.address_set_add(name) self.assertRaises(RuntimeError, cmd.execute, check_error=True) def test_addr_set_add_may_exist(self): name = utils.get_rand_device_name() addr_set = self._addr_set_add(name) addr_set2 = self.api.address_set_add( name, may_exist=True).execute(check_error=True) self.assertEqual(addr_set, addr_set2) def test_addr_set_add_with_addresses(self): addresses = ['192.168.0.1', '192.168.0.2'] addr_set = self._addr_set_add(addresses=addresses) self.assertEqual(addresses, addr_set.addresses) def test_addr_set_del(self): addr_set = self._addr_set_add() self.api.address_set_del(addr_set.uuid).execute(check_error=True) self.assertNotIn(addr_set.uuid, self.table.rows) def test_addr_set_del_by_name(self): name = utils.get_rand_device_name() self._addr_set_add(name) self.api.address_set_del(name).execute(check_error=True) def test_addr_set_del_no_exist(self): name = utils.get_rand_device_name() cmd = self.api.address_set_del(name) self.assertRaises(RuntimeError, cmd.execute, check_error=True) def test_addr_set_del_if_exists(self): name = utils.get_rand_device_name() self.api.address_set_del( name, if_exists=True).execute(check_error=True) def test_addr_set_list(self): addr_sets = {self._addr_set_add() for _ in range(3)} found_sets = set(self.api.address_set_list().execute(check_error=True)) self.assertTrue(addr_sets.issubset(found_sets)) def test_addr_set_add_addresses(self): addresses = ['192.168.0.1', '192.168.0.2'] addr_set = self._addr_set_add() self.api.address_set_add_addresses( addr_set.uuid, addresses).execute(check_error=True) self.assertEqual(addresses, addr_set.addresses) self.api.address_set_add_addresses( addr_set.uuid, addresses).execute(check_error=True) self.assertEqual(addresses, addr_set.addresses) def test_addr_set_remove_addresses(self): addresses = ['192.168.0.1', '192.168.0.2'] addr_set = self._addr_set_add(addresses=addresses) self.api.address_set_remove_addresses( addr_set.uuid, addresses).execute(check_error=True) self.assertEqual(addr_set.addresses, []) self.api.address_set_remove_addresses( addr_set.uuid, addresses).execute(check_error=True) self.assertEqual(addr_set.addresses, []) def test_addr_set_add_remove_addresses_by_str(self): address = "192.168.0.1" addr_set = self._addr_set_add() self.api.address_set_add_addresses( addr_set.uuid, address).execute(check_error=True) self.assertEqual([address], addr_set.addresses) self.api.address_set_remove_addresses( addr_set.uuid, address).execute(check_error=True) self.assertEqual([], addr_set.addresses)

commit_message:
Notify the need for overriding the default driver for Mellanox NIC

In case of mellanox cards, the interfaces used for DPDK ports
shall not be bound with vfio-pci (default) driver. An explicit error
message shall be thrown when the required drivers are not specified
in the user templates.

Change-Id: I69b362079905c3957504e4958abfeeb9923cf07f
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/os-net-config refs/changes/99/819999/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: if common.is_mellanox_interface(ifname) and 'vfio-pci' in driver: msg = ("For Mellanox NIC %s, the default driver vfio-pci " "needs to be overridden" % ifname) raise OvsDpdkBindException(msg) if common.is_mellanox_interface(ifname):

subject: Use centos mirror content instead of compose
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2021-11-09 08:25:14.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/tripleo-quickstart/commit/35c91f4281f04c9bbb0aa16f54ea3ee810350c58', 'message': 'Use centos mirror content instead of compose

Currently CentOS stream contents are pre-released on
http://mirror.stream.centos.org/9-stream.

In TripleO Deployment, we are using compose to lay down the repos.
But on the base system, It has contents from CentOS stream mirror
where module metadata is coming and but those contents are not
available in Compose.

Due to mixing of compose and mirror content, packages
which are not available in compose are getting filtered out.

In order to avoid this issue, we are switching to
CentOS Stream mirror content.

Depends-On: https://review.opendev.org/c/opendev/system-config/+/817136

Closes-Bug: 1949601

Signed-off-by: Chandan Kumar (raukadah) <chkumar@redhat.com>
Change-Id: I480dbb83d4721a30c0d96913df3e2a9d57ea4f75

Due to mixing of compose and mirror content, packages
which are not available in compose are getting filtered out.

In order to avoid this issue, we are switching to
CentOS Stream mirror content. Patch at [1] adds c9 stream mirror
for opendev system-config repo.

Also removes the use of lookup plugin as it caused problems
for zuul native execution see [2]. Instead ansible_env can
give us the same value.

[1] https://review.opendev.org/c/opendev/system-config/+/817136
[2] https://logserver.rdoproject.org/17/36817/4/check/tripleo-stream9-development-buildimage-overcloud-hardened-uefi-full-master/31ebe5e/job-output.txt

commit_message:
Use centos mirror content instead of compose

Currently CentOS stream contents are pre-released on
http://mirror.stream.centos.org/9-stream.

In TripleO Deployment, we are using compose to lay down the repos.
But on the base system, It has contents from CentOS stream mirror
where module metadata is coming and but those contents are not
available in Compose.

Due to mixing of compose and mirror content, packages
which are not available in compose are getting filtered out.

In order to avoid this issue, we are switching to
CentOS Stream mirror content. Patch at [1] adds c9 stream mirror
for opendev system-config repo.

Also removes the use of lookup plugin as it caused problems
for zuul native execution see [2]. Instead ansible_env can
give us the same value.
Also carries workaround for opendev centos9 stream repos
until [3] or similar fix merges.

[1] https://review.opendev.org/c/opendev/system-config/+/817136
[2] https://logserver.rdoproject.org/17/36817/4/check/tripleo-stream9-development-buildimage-overcloud-hardened-uefi-full-master/31ebe5e/job-output.txt
[3] https://review.opendev.org/c/opendev/base-jobs/+/820018

Closes-Bug: 1949601

Co-Authored-By: Marios Andreou (marios) <mandreou@redhat.com>
Signed-off-by: Chandan Kumar (raukadah) <chkumar@redhat.com>
Change-Id: I480dbb83d4721a30c0d96913df3e2a9d57ea4f75

commit_message:
Don't override images client in compute admin tests

Tests should be explicit about their use of admin credentials. The
base compute admin tests class overrode self.image_client with the
admin version. Stop doing that, and introduce a new
self.admin_image_client client that tests can explicitly use.

Needed-by: https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/whitebox-tempest-plugin/+/805300
Change-Id: I1a0c84b41b1b77d3a618a8f15448909bd12a0742
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/tempest refs/changes/62/820062/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: cls.admin_image_client = cls.os_admin.image_client_v2

commit_message:
Fix race condition in the sink when deleting records

Updated the sink to behave closer to how we handle this type
of operations in designate.api.v2.

- Added object validation to all requests.
- Better test coverage.
- Use recordset update / delete instead of just record delete.

Closes-Bug: #1947765
Change-Id: I867600eb48a3e30a4d17471ab794ca717706823d
(cherry picked from commit 4807c23228fbb23af3087ee072bf73d7fc43aff5)

commit_message:
Pass crush hierarchy data as extra_var

When the Ceph cluster is run, for each OSD the operator can define
an osd crush location (like it used to do with ceph-ansible [1]).
This patch adds to the overcloud ceph deploy command the ability to
accept an additional argument that represents the path where the
hierarchy map is defined.

[1] https://github.com/ceph/ceph-ansible/blob/master/tests/functional/all_daemons/container/hosts

Change-Id: Idd0296928246359e2dbb95f5163f32b653af55a3
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/python-tripleoclient refs/changes/15/819815/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: spec_group.add_argument('--crush-hierarchy', help=_( "Path to an existing crush hierarchy spec " "file. "), default=None) if parsed_args.crush_hierarchy: if not os.path.exists(parsed_args.crush_hierarchy): raise oscexc.CommandError( "Crush Hierarchy Spec file not found --crush-hierarchy %s." % os.path.abspath(parsed_args.crush_hierarchy)) else: extra_vars['crush_hierarchy_path'] = \ os.path.abspath(parsed_args.crush_hierarchy)

commit_message:
Enable setting whole_disk_images=true for wallaby

This is enables wallaby jobs to use whole_disk_images
if set to true.

Change-Id: I21e7893a5b8c8979fd982934d89d86ea7a806328

commit_message:
Use admin_client to list admin's servers' ports

FloatingIpTestCasesAdmin creates VMs as admin (to be sure to boot on
availability_zone) so to list ports for the VM we have to use
admin_client.

Change-Id: I1da9ccc99b70355554ace3a20a237bb4f33381ab
Closes-Bug: #1952806

commit_message:
Inherit default galera_wait_timeout value from openstack_db_connection_recycle_time

Set a new default value for ``galera_wait_timeout`` which is inherited from global ``openstack_db_connection_recycle_time``.

These variables are directly related, it would cause errors when ``galera_wait_timeout`` is lower than ``openstack_db_connection_recycle_time``.
From the other hand, I don't see any reason for ``galera_wait_timeout`` to be higher than ``openstack_db_connection_recycle_time`` in most cases.

Change-Id: I9450912ec7960a8ab713517532164cab52628b30
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/openstack-ansible-galera_server refs/changes/25/819425/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: galera_wait_timeout: "{{ openstack_db_connection_recycle_time }}"

Added following variables to be used as default values for database connection pooling in openstack-ansible roles:

- ``openstack_db_max_overflow: 50`` - oslo.db's default
- ``openstack_db_max_pool_size: 5`` - oslo.db's default
- ``openstack_db_pool_timeout: 30`` - sqlalchemy's default
- ``openstack_db_connection_recycle_time: 600`` - long enough to not affect performance and short enough to avoid reaching max_connections limit during keepalived failovers in most cases.

commit_message:
From now on, we will change default values for database connection pooling in each role

- ``openstack_db_max_overflow: 50`` - oslo.db's default
- ``openstack_db_max_pool_size: 5`` - oslo.db's default
- ``openstack_db_pool_timeout: 30`` - sqlalchemy's default
- ``openstack_db_connection_recycle_time: 600`` - long enough to not affect performance and short enough to avoid reaching max_connections limit during keepalived failovers in most cases.

Most of the default values look fine so I didn't want to overwrite them. However, if they won't be suitable for someone, they can change them here so it won't be needed to set them independently for each role

Change-Id: I5cccbbcf41fdf270e38c5b272638fe6d848de5c1
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/openstack-ansible refs/changes/24/819424/6 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: ## SQLAlchemy pooling options openstack_db_max_overflow: 50 openstack_db_max_pool_size: 5 openstack_db_pool_timeout: 30 openstack_db_connection_recycle_time: 600

commit_message:
Fix error in dynamic-address-fact task

When a dynamic_address_gather_filter is set and the inventory
data does not generate the dynamic inventory variable
container_networks[network_address]['bridge'], the task will
fail, as even though dynamic_address_gather_filter is defined
the jinja template will still try to evaluate
container_networks[network_address]['bridge'].

This patch fixes this by setting a default value if
container_networks[network_address]['bridge'] is not defined

Change-Id: I39082bee2435781d87f653e66fd55a92397c5572
(cherry picked from commit 3504694b4afb4792357c816631c6ddd6cfdde9e3)
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/openstack-ansible refs/changes/92/820092/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: filter: "{{ dynamic_address_gather_filter | default(('ansible_' ~ default_network_interface_name) | replace('-','_')) }}" vars: default_network_interface_name: "{{ container_networks[network_address]['bridge'] | default }}" - (dynamic_address_gather_filter is defined) or (default_network_interface_name | length > 0)
deleted_lines: filter: "{{ dynamic_address_gather_filter | default(('ansible_' ~ container_networks[network_address]['bridge']) | replace('-','_')) }}" - (dynamic_address_gather_filter is defined) or (container_networks[network_address] is defined and container_networks[network_address]['bridge'] is defined)

commit_message:
Add options to disable automatic scheduling and failover of BGP speakers

Sometimes it is not desirable to reschedule BGP speakers to
another DrAgents, especially in cases when the speaker must
run on a specific DrAgent in a specific place in the network
topology. This commit adds configuration flags which allow to
disable automatic scheduling of new BGP speakers on DrAgents,
and  rescheduling in case of DrAgent failure, so the speaker
is bound to the same DrAgent, even if the the agent is down.

Change-Id: I5364749e7a4009230a8b8174ad599cf40a24f415
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/neutron-dynamic-routing refs/changes/75/780675/3 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: help=_('Driver used for scheduling BGP speakers to BGP DrAgent')), cfg.BoolOpt( 'allow_automatic_dragent_failover', default=True, help=_('Automatically remove BGP speakers from offline DrAgents.'))
deleted_lines: help=_('Driver used for scheduling BGP speakers to BGP DrAgent'))

commit_message:
fedora: reuse DIB_FEDORA_SUBRELEASE if set

Reuse the value of DIB_FEDORA_SUBRELEASE if the environment variable
exists.

revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2021-11-24 14:28:06.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/ovsdbapp/commit/062fe6603c44ca59357585bc0010dba6da3e784f', 'message': 'Check WaitEvents for match after other events

It is useful to be able to have an Event that takes an action
when matched on a particular condition, e.g. "create a neutron
agent when a Chassis is created" and to be able to create a
WaitEvent that would fire on the same condition, *after* the other
event is finished. E.g. "after the neutron agent is created, call
get_agent() to verify that it is there."

Since RowEventHandler._watched_events is a set, events are not
ordered, so sometimes the WaitEvent matches before the other
event, and things fail.

This patch automatically adds WaitEvents to their own set, and
has _watched_events be the chain of the set of normal events
followed by WaitEvents. This keeps the same algorithmic complexity
for discarding events and avoids changing the API in any way.

commit_message:
Check WaitEvents for match after other events

It is useful to be able to have an Event that takes an action
when matched on a particular condition, e.g. "create a neutron
agent when a Chassis is created" and to be able to create a
WaitEvent that would fire on the same condition, *after* the other
event is finished. E.g. "after the neutron agent is created, call
get_agent() to verify that it is there."

Since RowEventHandler._watched_events is a set, events are not
ordered, so sometimes the WaitEvent matches before the other
event, and things fail.

This patch automatically adds a priority queue, with RowEvent and
WaitEvent assigned appropriate priorities that will ensure that
WaitEvents are processed later than RowEvents.

Co-authored-by: Jakub Libosvar <libosvar@redhat.com>
Change-Id: I14980aa57541962742faf4ca72ed0bd3ce6e20e3
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/ovsdbapp refs/changes/16/819116/7 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: import itertools self._events = set() self._wait_events = set() def _get_queue(self, event): if isinstance(event, WaitEvent): return self._wait_events return self._watched_events @property def _watched_events(self): return itertools.chain(self._events, self._wait_events) def _add(self, event): self._get_queue(event).add(event) def _discard(self, event): self._get_queue(event).discard(event) self._add(event) def watch(self, events): self._add(event) self._discard(event) def unwatch(self, events): self._discard(event)
deleted_lines: self._watched_events = set() self._watched_events.add(event) def watch_events(self, events): self._watched_events.add(event) self._watched_events.discard(event) def unwatch_events(self, events): self._watched_events.discard(event)

commit_message:
Fix placement upgrade playbook condition

We don't need to explicitly create placement.yml when compute-infra_hosts
were not defined.
Once os-infra_hosts are defined in openstack_user_config, that is enough
for placement hosts to be created with new env.d file in place [1]

https: //opendev.org/openstack/openstack-ansible/src/branch/stable/train/inventory/env.d/placement.yml#L25
Change-Id: I4df44d26ebb14e3c11bb861e3540a1f4cec6010e

subject: Fix mysql_upgrade possible race condition
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2021-12-01 12:08:38.000000000', 'files': ['tasks/galera_server_setup.yml'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/openstack-ansible-galera_server/commit/6a0c2fc9798f64a36de6676fbdca44ca81eea6cb', 'message': "Fix mysql_upgrade possible race condition

On deb packages of MariaDB, mysql_upgrade is ran with debian-start
script as systemd post-run step. This means, that we don't really have
control when it's launched and we need to wait until process
is finished before proceeding with it's setup.
In the meanwhile redhat is packaged differently and mysql_upgrade
must be run manually.

Based on that we change ordering and verifying explicitly that
upgrade has finished.

Change-Id: Ib0f410cfcdcc416b58b03febab9c55dc7982de38
(cherry picked from commit c8575032749dd47f11967c482f122af313f8ee25)
"}]
commit_message:
Fix mysql_upgrade possible race condition

On deb packages of MariaDB, mysql_upgrade is ran with debian-start
script as systemd post-run step. This means, that we don't really have
control when it's launched and we need to wait until process
is finished before proceeding with it's setup.
In the meanwhile redhat is packaged differently and mysql_upgrade
must be run manually.

Based on that we change ordering and verifying explicitly that
upgrade has finished.

Change-Id: Ib0f410cfcdcc416b58b03febab9c55dc7982de38
(cherry picked from commit c8575032749dd47f11967c482f122af313f8ee25)
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/openstack-ansible-galera_server refs/changes/43/819843/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: - name: Run MySQL Upgrade command: /usr/bin/mariadb-upgrade --version-check register: galera_mysql_upgrade changed_when: - not galera_mysql_upgrade.stdout is search("already upgraded") until: galera_mysql_upgrade is success when: ansible_facts['os_family'] | lower == 'redhat' retries: 3 delay: 10 # NOTE(noonedeadpunk): debian-start runs mariadb-upgrade with systemd unit so we # need to wait for it to finish to avoid race conditions - name: Wait for MySQL Upgrade to finish wait_for: path: /var/lib/mysql/mysql_upgrade_info search_regex: "^{{ galera_major_version }}.{{ galera_minor_version }}"
deleted_lines: - name: Run MySQL Upgrade command: /usr/bin/mysql_upgrade register: galera_mysql_upgrade changed_when: - not galera_mysql_upgrade.stdout is search("already upgraded") until: galera_mysql_upgrade is success retries: 3 delay: 10

commit_message:
Database connection pooling improvements

- Implemented new variable ``connection_recycle_time`` responsible for SQLAlchemy's connection recycling
- Set new default values for db pooling variables which are inherited from the global ones.

commit_message:
[release] Set previous_release to xena

This defines which release we upgrade from in CI.

commit_message:
Expansion of logging for the run action.

Logging statements related to the run action
in validation_actions.py were expanded.

New debug level logging statements introduced.

One of the testing constants in the fakes.py was altered
as it was not accurate representation of real data,
and as such was breaking the new logging statements
during unit test runs.

Signed-off-by: Jiri Podivin <jpodivin@redhat.com>
Change-Id: Ic308a76f4f6af6e7fe64930e84360bfb4ed587be

commit_message:
Add a StaticScheduler without automatic scheduling

The automatic scheduling that was introduced in [0] is having some
issues. Add a StaticScheduler that can be used as an alternative for
deployments that want explicit control over where their BGP speakers are
getting scheduled.

Add a job that runs with the new scheduler.

[0] https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/neutron-dynamic-routing/+/478455

Depends-On: https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/neutron-tempest-plugin/+/815294
Closes-Bug: 1920065
Signed-off-by: Dr. Jens Harbott <harbott@osism.tech>
Change-Id: Ib7fcd0c7371bc75089b10024ee1b6e75c98f0188

subject: keypair: copy key to deploy host rather than setup host
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2021-12-02 10:20:46.000000000', 'files': ['tasks/octavia_keypair.yml'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/openstack-ansible-os_octavia/commit/29287119f58fadf5f0122fa8f023b9d92d2636c9', 'message': "keypair: copy key to deploy host rather than setup host

The env lookup in the key copying task refers to the deploy host.
If your deploy host user is not root then this task will fail
as this directory does not exist on the remote setup host.

As the original intention appears to have been to copy the result
of the keypair generation to the deploy host, the delegation is
explicitly set to 'localhost'.

Change-Id: I89649503d5918c33f0d1e4200be67be5e0ed8a9e
(cherry picked from commit ffac17201a735115267648b657399ad9fc4be9ae)
"}]
commit_message:
keypair: copy key to deploy host rather than setup host

The env lookup in the key copying task refers to the deploy host.
If your deploy host user is not root then this task will fail
as this directory does not exist on the remote setup host.

As the original intention appears to have been to copy the result
of the keypair generation to the deploy host, the delegation is
explicitly set to 'localhost'.

Change-Id: I89649503d5918c33f0d1e4200be67be5e0ed8a9e
(cherry picked from commit ffac17201a735115267648b657399ad9fc4be9ae)

commit_message:
Ensure max_connections is calculated correctly with integers

The '*' operator can do string concatenation or integer multiply.
Ensure that we work on integers.

See https://paste.opendev.org/show/810346/

Change-Id: Ia2c3785fcab4d70e29b8be8c29b8aa81ef6ec5a8
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/openstack-ansible-galera_server refs/changes/58/820058/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

[WIP] Use a local call instead of RPC for the combined service

Change-Id: I5499e91473dbe0158f53dca5d5d886233c9635aa
Story: #2009676
Task: #44103

added_lines: class LocalContext: """Context to make calls to a local conductor.""" __slots__ = () def call(self, context, rpc_call_name, **kwargs): """Make a local conductor call.""" if rpc.GLOBAL_MANAGER is None: raise exception.ServiceUnavailable( _("The built-in conductor is not available, it might have " "creashed")) return getattr(rpc.GLOBAL_MANAGER, rpc_call_name)(context, **kwargs) def can_send_version(self, version): # NOTE(dtantsur): in single-process mode the versions match between # the API and the conductor. return True _LOCAL_CONTEXT = LocalContext() def _prepare_call(self, topic, version=None): """Prepare an RPC call. If a conductor exists in the same process, a direct function call is used instead of real RPC. """ # FIXME(dtantsur): this doesn't work with either JSON RPC or local # conductor. Do we even need this fallback? topic = topic or self.topic # Normally a topic is a <topic prefix>.<hostname>, we need to extract # the hostname to match it against the current host. host = topic[len(self.topic) + 1:] if rpc.GLOBAL_MANAGER is not None and host == CONF.host: # Short-cut to a local function call if there is a built-in # conductor. return _LOCAL_CONTEXT # Normal RPC path subject: Introduce "response_format" for the V2 summary API
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2021-02-08 17:14:18.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/cloudkitty/commit/01261e45e6802e6770809c505b76fb7d99f36107', 'message': 'Introduce "response_format" for the V2 summary API

The V2 summary endpoint uses a quite unconventional data format in
the response. Currently, the format is the following:

```
{"total": <number of elements in the response>,
 "results": [array of arrays of data],
 "columns": [array of columns]}
```

To process this, we need to find the index of a column in the column
list, and with this index, we retrieve the data in the array of data
that is found in the array of results. The proposal is to use the
following format in the response.

```
{"total": <number of elements in the response>,
 "results": [array of objects/dictionary]}
```

With this new format, one does not need to consult the index of a
column to retrieve data in one of the entries. We would only need to
retrieve the data in the entry using its column name. Therefore, the
coding feels more natural. To maintain compatibility, this new format
would be only applied when an option is sent to CloudKitty via
`response_format` option.

Change-Id: I5869d527e6e4655c653b6852d6fb7bebc9d71520

commit_message:
Introduce "response_format" for the V2 summary API

The V2 summary endpoint uses a quite unconventional data format in
the response. Currently, the format is the following:

```
{"total": <number of elements in the response>,
 "results": [array of arrays of data],
 "columns": [array of columns]}
```

To process this, we need to find the index of a column in the column
list, and with this index, we retrieve the data in the array of data
that is found in the array of results. The proposal is to use the
following format in the response.

```
{"total": <number of elements in the response>,
 "results": [array of objects/dictionary]}
```

With this new format, one does not need to consult the index of a
column to retrieve data in one of the entries. We would only need to
retrieve the data in the entry using its column name. Therefore, the
coding feels more natural. To maintain compatibility, this new format
would be only applied when an option is sent to CloudKitty via
`response_format` option.

Depends-on: https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/cloudkitty/+/793973

Change-Id: I5869d527e6e4655c653b6852d6fb7bebc9d71520

commit_message:
Use config_template as a collection

Since we still use ceph-ansible that has their own implementation of
config_template module it's worth to use mentioned module as a collection
explicitly.

Depends-On: https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/openstack-ansible/+/819814
Depends-On: https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/openstack-ansible-os_nova/+/820110

commit_message:
Update versions_url for downstream case

For version_url: We should not track master for all downstream
branches, because when package version difference between
older branch and master, rpm build could get skip.

For example: Faced below in 16.2
~~~
python-networking-ovn not present
in https://trunk.rdoproject.org/centos8-master/current/versions.csv
- skipping.
~~~

Adding release var so that correct upstream branch
versions_url is used.

Change-Id: I4504a8291fc69a42b181b5b09cfc3ecb3351cfa1
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/tripleo-quickstart-extras refs/changes/33/820033/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: versions_url=https://trunk.rdoproject.org/centos8-{{ release }}/current/versions.csv

commit_message:
Updating yoga tested python versions in classifier

Yoga testing runtime has been updated with py38 and py39
as voting and removed the py36 testing. Unit tests update are
handled by the job template change in openstack-zuul-job and you
can see the updated jobs running in gate.

- https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/openstack-zuul-jobs/+/818609

this commit updates the tested py versions in setup.cfg classifier.

[1] https://governance.openstack.org/tc/reference/runtimes/yoga.html

Change-Id: Id5b91de2ec099500d84972f008fd914dcc458cfe

commit_message:
Refactor galera_use_ssl behaviour

With PKI role in place in most cases you don't need to explicitly
provide path to the CA file because PKI role ensures that CA is trusted
by the system overall. In the meanwhile in PyMySQL [1] you must either
provide CA file or cert/key or enable verify.

Since current behaviour is to provide path to the custom CA we expect
certificate being trusted overall. Thus we enable cert verification when
galera_use_ssl is True.

[1] https://github.com/PyMySQL/PyMySQL/blob/78f0cf99e5d5351df0821442e4dc35c49a6390c6/pymysql/connections.py#L267

Change-Id: I8b7b266d2a0633b40d38581e734ad00714b89885

commit_message:
Add destructive field flag to export configuration

New optional parameter added to export configuration method to control
if destructive iDRAC settings, such as those that could cause loss of
network access, are exported. It is also unlikely that these fields
are necessary during import to replicate same static IP address
settings. User can still put these fields back during import.

Change-Id: Iad39267fedf1c1a7381d03152eb0cea0c114eede

commit_message:
Fix amphora image size display in diskimage-create.sh script

The size of the amphora image was not shown at the end of the
diskimage-screate.sh script due to missing file extenstion.
The extension is set based on the AMP_IMAGETYPE variable.

story: 2009688
Change-Id: I1cbced187c054391039933d2ba5abeaf93d80754

commit_message:
Allow Swift to configure secure RBAC options

This defines default RBAC roles for the Swift proxy container
if EnforceSecureRbac is True.

Depends-On: https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/puppet-swift/+/807069
Depends-On: https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/tripleo-heat-templates/+/818901
Change-Id: I6dc60ff5a06799de4929ebe213d3c061b182754a
(cherry picked from commit 762f5056d5d78ff58ee29962443ecc422dc1e980)
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/tripleo-heat-templates refs/changes/02/818902/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: EnforceSecureRbac: type: boolean default: false description: >- Setting this option to True will configure each OpenStack service to enforce Secure RBAC by setting `[oslo_policy] enforce_new_defaults` and `[oslo_policy] enforce_scope` to True. This introduces a consistent set of RBAC personas across OpenStack services that include support for system and project scope, as well as keystone's default roles, admin, member, and reader. Do not enable this functionality until all services in your deployment actually support secure RBAC.<<<<<<< HEAD (baaaf8 Merge "Implement a tool for converting policy.yaml files to )======= - {get_param: EnforceSecureRbac} - swift::proxy::keystone::project_reader_roles: ['SwiftProjectReader'] - swift::proxy::keystone::system_reader_roles: ['SwiftSystemReader'] - if: - {get_param: SwiftEncryptionEnabled} - swift::keymaster::key_id: 'test_id' >>>>>>> CHANGE (762f50 Allow Swift to configure secure RBAC options)

commit_message:
Add a global configuration option for secure RBAC

This commit adds a single option that we can use to turn secure RBAC on
in all the OpenStack services. This is a contrasting approach to using
service-specific variables.

We don't intend anyone to use this functionality until we can update
each OpenStack service to use the correct token when communicating with
other services. Deployers should also only use this if they are sure all
services in their deployment actually support secure RBAC, which might
not be for a while, but this allows us to lay down the plumbing in each
service to turn it on now, which will be useful for testing and flushing
out what we need to change in TripleO as well as the upstream services.

Change-Id: I13262a4f1a6e850d66b2c687e730e0c2004c1f29
(cherry picked from commit 57a8efd4077d4ba7c39a48834eac9e14e78edc08)
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/tripleo-heat-templates refs/changes/01/818901/4 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: <<<<<<< HEAD (baaaf8 Merge "Implement a tool for converting policy.yaml files to ) ======= AdminToken: description: The password for the keystone admin account, used for monitoring, querying neutron etc. default: '' type: string hidden: true EnforceSecureRbac: type: boolean default: false description: >- Setting this option to True will configure each OpenStack service to enforce Secure RBAC by setting `[oslo_policy] enforce_new_defaults` and `[oslo_policy] enforce_scope` to True. This introduces a consistent set of RBAC personas across OpenStack services that include support for system and project scope, as well as keystone's default roles, admin, member, and reader. Do not enable this functionality until all services in your deployment actually support secure RBAC. parameter_groups: - label: deprecated description: | The following parameters are deprecated and will be removed. They should not be relied on for new deployments. If you have concerns regarding deprecated parameters, please contact the TripleO development team on IRC or the OpenStack mailing list. parameters: - AdminToken >>>>>>> CHANGE (57a8ef Add a global configuration option for secure RBAC)

commit_message:
[api-ref] Fix datatype of cast_rules_to_readonly

Fixing cast_rules_to_readonly type from string to boolean
for share instances and share replicas.

The API-REF had the wrong type for these fields.

Closes-Bug: #1948717

Change-Id: Ie8defe1fcb03bced9887ba1b41d5b062ba477924

subject: Fix notifications for Cinder
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2021-11-30 12:04:32.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/openstack-helm/commit/f29bc72dd7cbb2e852dc2ecee02137d36a648e12', 'message': 'Fix notifications for Cinder

At the moment, the Cinder usage audit runs every 5 minutes which
is excessive and causes load on the system.  Also, it defaults to
auditing an entire month which can take ages for large systems.

This patch makes it run sanely at the 5th minute of ever hour and
also runs the audit for the past hour only.

commit_message:
Fix notifications for Cinder

At the moment, the Cinder usage audit runs every 5 minutes which
is excessive and causes load on the system.  Also, it defaults to
auditing an entire month which can take ages for large systems.

This patch makes it run sanely at the 5th minute of ever hour and
also runs the audit for the past hour only.

Change-Id: I59d1230fa4d33a2cf0364ade1a710e65ef449057
Signed-off-by: Mohammed Naser <mnaser@vexxhost.com>
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/openstack-helm refs/changes/12/819812/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: cron: "5 * * * *" volume_usage_audit_period: hour

commit_message:
Fix LB set in ERROR too early in the revert flow

When an error occurs in a flow, the provisioning status of the load
balancer should be set to ERROR in the revert method of the first task
of the flow. This update acts as an unlock of the LB object and cannot
occur in any other revert method because the API might consider the LB
as mutable before finishing a task/flow.

Remove all occurrences of mark_loadbalancer_prov_status_error calls in
revert method of tasks that are not specifically designed for unlocking
the load balancers. Add a LoadBalancerToErrorOnRevertTask task in the
amphora failover flow to prevent a LB to be in an immutable state.

Story 2009651
Task 43810
Story 2009652
Task 43811

Note for stable/train: the code of the amphorav2 is not updated in this
backport, the source files exist in train but the feature was added
ussuri. Backporting this patch creates many merge conflicts and doesn't
provide anything for train users.

Conflicts:
	octavia/controller/worker/v1/tasks/database_tasks.py
	octavia/controller/worker/v2/flows/amphora_flows.py
	octavia/controller/worker/v2/tasks/amphora_driver_tasks.py
	octavia/controller/worker/v2/tasks/database_tasks.py

	octavia/tests/unit/controller/worker/v2/tasks/test_database_tasks.py

commit_message:
Fix LB set in ERROR too early in MapLoadbalancerToAmphora

This is a follow up patch for I48b0f5a773209b1c1b056d71c0da05d6fd82ca73,
this fix applies only on Wallaby and older releases because the code was
removed during the Xena cycle.

It removes calls to mark_loadbalancer_prov_status_error in revert method
of tasks (except in LoadBalancer*ToErrorOnRevertTask)

Story 2009651
Task 43810
Story 2009652
Task 43811

commit_message:
Fix LB set in ERROR too early in the revert flow

When an error occurs in a flow, the provisioning status of the load
balancer should be set to ERROR in the revert method of the first task
of the flow. This update acts as an unlock of the LB object and cannot
occur in any other revert method because the API might consider the LB
as mutable before finishing a task/flow.

Remove all occurrences of mark_loadbalancer_prov_status_error calls in
revert method of tasks that are not specifically designed for unlocking
the load balancers. Add a LoadBalancerToErrorOnRevertTask task in the
amphora failover flow to prevent a LB to be in an immutable state.

Story 2009651
Task 43810
Story 2009652
Task 43811

Change-Id: I48b0f5a773209b1c1b056d71c0da05d6fd82ca73
(cherry picked from commit 4b8b198fecee802e1031c014f811eb766329a1a0)
(cherry picked from commit 4039d35ce221b58490d4aa5b3497e29dbf7664ac)

Change-Id: Ibd22a1697d0f3106531f1126a75dedbd7f2538ed
"}]
commit_message:
Configure HAProxy to check Horizon's login page

This makes sure that a 500 error returned by Horizon will be caught by
HAProxy. By checking / we were always getting a 302 redirect to the
login page and were therefore missing any 500 error behind.

Change-Id: Ibd22a1697d0f3106531f1126a75dedbd7f2538ed

commit_message:
Make Keystone_all group configurable

We want to be able use a big inventory with many hosts and we want to maintain more than one 
OpenStack Cluster, which different keystone machines. 

So our Idea is to make a variable to allow to override the keystone_all group if needed.

Change-Id: I94dfa9e450eaf8923efe205f319c01a5cd06f65d

commit_message:
Fix PKI include condition

In order for AIO to pass against ironic role, we need to cover the case
when ironic_compute == nova_compute host. For that we use more
common condition and verifying virt_type which must be set for
Ironic.

Change-Id: I7540e4c6848bad80c368a1227b09437428fe64a2
Closes-Bug: #1952649

commit_message:
Fix libvirt service name

This patch fixes an error encounter within the processmonitor. The
libvirt service name has been changed from libvirt-bin (doesn't exist)
to libvirtd. Tested on Ubuntu Server 20.04 (Focal).

Change-Id: I6f909cb0dec22db6b3ab05d2158ac6e0601f9ad3

commit_message:
Add openstacksdk-functional-devstack in integrated gates

openstacksdk-functional-devstack should be part of
integrated gate so that cross service-sdk testing
can be covered to avoid any regression.

commit_message:
Use config_template as a collection

Since we still use ceph-ansible that has their own implementation of
config_template module it's worth to use mentioned module as a collection
explicitly.

Depends-On: https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/openstack-ansible/+/819814
Depends-On: https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/openstack-ansible-tests/+/819897

commit_message:
[tripleo] Adding tripleo-docs to independent deliverables

tripleo-docs is not yet listed among deliverables. This patch adds it
with some basic settings.

Change-Id: I96f7c5fac4c5b875e8261f291892701fab89859c
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/releases refs/changes/87/818887/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: --- launchpad: tripleo-docs release-model: untagged team: tripleo type: trailing repository-settings: openstack/tripleo-docs: {}

commit_message:
WIP: First attempt at a ArributeRateLimit Iterator

This is a very rough first attempt of an iterator, mostly built out of
trail and error. Next need to refactor and clean up.. if it works.

The basic idea is it uses a series of RateLimitedIterators for each
attribute of the given item from the iterator it wraps. In essence to
turn a stram of items, say:

   aabccbbbacaccb

Into:
   aaaa
   bbbbb
   ccccc

And applies are ratelimit to each category. The hard part is something
in say 'a' is still waiting we should check the `b's`, etc. So there
there is a bit of hacking to get RateLimitedIterators to return a
StopIteration while they are all the cateforie RateLimitedIters are
chained together.
But this also leads to having to restart the iterators. Although maybe I
could play with the cycle and islice itertool iterators to stop and
continue or something? (Just thought of that while writing this up).

Restarting iterators means we have to be careful will popping the
already yeilded items from the category/attribute buffer lists.

In ascii art it looks something like:

             
                                  
               RateLimittedIter*  A A A   
                                  
               RateLimittedIter*  B       
 Chain                      
               RateLimittedIter*  C C     
                                  
               RateLimittedIter*  D       
                                  
                                 
                                      
                                      
                                      
                                          
                                       A A A B C C D A 
                                           
                                                                 
                                                                 

                                                       Next from wrapped iter

  * - it indicating it's using a hacked RateLimitIter to return
    StopIteration.

Change-Id: Ic26d224f467c838e05411abc5989bf5c043773e0
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/swift refs/changes/99/817699/4 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: self.stop_instead_of_sleep = False stop_iteration = None if self.stop_instead_of_sleep: stop_iteration = StopIteration self.elements_per_second, throw=stop_iteration)class AttributedRateLimitedIterator(object): """ If you look from a distance it looks a little like this:     RateLimittedIter* A A A      RateLimittedIter* B      Chain    RateLimittedIter* C C       RateLimittedIter* D               A A A B C C D A     Next from wrapped iter 1. It wraps an iterator. 2. On next() it'll first attempt to get something thats ready from the attribute map of RateLimitted iterators. Note: that instead of sleeping the RateLimmited iterator will return a StopIteration moving to the next in the chain. 3. If there is nothing from the chain, it'll grab something from the wrapped iterator and add it to the attribute rate limiters. 4. Check for anything new/ready again. 5. if the wrapped gets depleated and there are still items waiting, then we start sleeping the minimum sleep until something should be ready. Caveats: Because we chain and call StopIteration on the RateLimiters, we need to reset the iterators everytime, which we need to do anyway because the rate attribute bucket/lists might have grown from the wrapped iterator. This means popping yielded values from the bucket is important or we'll call the same objects again and again :( """ def __init__(self, iterable, attribute, elements_per_second, limit_after=0): self.iterator = iter(iterable) self.elements_per_second = elements_per_second self.limit_after = limit_after self.attribute = attribute self.per_attribute_iters = {None: ( RateLimitedIterator([], self.elements_per_second, self.limit_after), [])} self.yielded = self.processed = 0 def __iter__(self): return self def add_value_to_iters(self, next_value): attr = getattr(next_value, self.attribute, None) if attr and attr not in self.per_attribute_iters: self.per_attribute_iters[attr] = ( RateLimitedIterator([], self.elements_per_second, self.limit_after), []) self.per_attribute_iters[attr][-1].append(next_value) self.processed += 1 def remove_value_from_iters(self, next_value): attr = getattr(next_value, self.attribute, None) self.per_attribute_iters[attr][-1].pop(0) def rebuild_iters(self): # rebuild attr iters because it's a chained iter and StopIterations # are thrown if an iter is still waiting. This does mean we do need to # make sure we clean up items once they're yielded. attr_iters = [] for attr_iter, attr_list in self.per_attribute_iters.values(): attr_iter.iterator = iter(attr_list) attr_iter.stop_instead_of_sleep = True attr_iters.append(attr_iter) for val in itertools.chain(*attr_iters): yield val def get_min_sleep(self): def get_running_time(item): return item[0].running_time next_time = min(map(get_running_time, self.per_attribute_iters.values())) sleep_interval = next_time - time.time() / 1000.0 return sleep_interval if sleep_interval > 0 else 0 def next(self): wrapped_iter_done = False while True: try: # if there is something available in our attr iters use it next_value = next(self.rebuild_iters()) self.yielded += 1 self.remove_value_from_iters(next_value) return next_value except StopIteration: # Either nothing is ready or nothing is in our iters so grab # one from the wrapped iter and add it to the attr iterators pass try: wrapped_value = next(self.iterator) self.add_value_to_iters(wrapped_value) except StopIteration: # We're out of values on the iter we're wrapping wrapped_iter_done = True if wrapped_iter_done: if self.yielded == self.processed: raise StopIteration eventlet.sleep(self.get_min_sleep()) __next__ = next def ratelimit_sleep(running_time, max_rate, incr_by=1, rate_buffer=5, throw=None): :param throw: Instead of sleep, throw the given throwable. This is used in the attributedRateLimiter. if throw is not None: raise throw()

commit_message:
Change signature of "sqlalchemy.events.ConnectionEvents.before_execute"

New method signature is:
  def before_execute(conn, clauseelement, multiparams, params,
                     execution_options)

Closes-Bug: #1952409

commit_message:
Use config_template as a collection

Since we still use ceph-ansible that has their own implementation of
config_template module it's worth to use mentioned module as a collection
explicitly.

Depends-On: https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/openstack-ansible/+/819814
